dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right. The tariffs. That's, um, that's where things get really interesting, because it’s not what you'd expect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. So, back in 2018, the Trump administration, like, cranked up tariffs on Chinese imports from just over 3% to *over 21%*. A level we hadn't seen since before WWII.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which, obviously, China didn't take lying down. They retaliated, pushing their tariffs on US imports from about 8% to, like, 19%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, obviously, China didn't take lying down. They retaliated, pushing their tariffs on U S imports from about eight percent to, like, nineteen percent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the thing is, a lot of people think these tariffs are just bad, right? But the article makes a pretty compelling case that, actually, a WTO panel in 2020 ruled that the Trump tariffs were completely aligned with international rules.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In any case, a WTO panel ruled in 2020 that the Trump tariffs are incompatible with Americas legal obligation to abide by the organizations rules.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's, uh, it's counter-intuitive. They argue that maintaining these tariffs actually *promotes* the rules-based international trading system. And this is the kicker: it benefits households and firms in both countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's, uh, it's counter-intuitive. They argue that maintaining these tariffs actually promotes the rules-based international trading system. And this is the kicker: it benefits households and firms in both countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US insistence on maintaining the tariffs not only undermines the rules-based international trading system, but also hurts households and firms in both countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Because you'd think, okay, remove the tariffs, prices go down for consumers. But almost every serious study suggests that the increased costs from tariffs haven't actually been passed on to American consumers.

dialogue_turns.text: No, they haven't. And if you remove them, the cost of living would actually *go up*. Directly, your household basket would increase by about half a percentage point.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, they haven't. And if you remove them, the cost of living would actually go up. Directly, your household basket would increase by about half a percentage point.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since imported goods account for about 12% of the US household-consumption basket, the removal of the Trump tariffs would lower the cost of that basket by about half a percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But that's just the start, um. Forty percent of our imports from China are, like, parts and components. So removing the tariffs would raise input costs for American manufacturers, pushing up prices on *American-made* goods too.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, the indirect effects, you know? Chinese imports become cheaper, competitive pressure on other countries—like Mexico, India—it wanes. So *their* prices would also rise. All told, it's, uh, about a one percentage point permanent raise in the cost of living.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, the indirect effects, you know? Chinese imports become cheaper, competitive pressure on other countries-like Mexico, India-it wanes. So their prices would also rise. All told, it's, uh, about a one percentage point permanent raise in the cost of living.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Chinese imports become cheaper, competitive pressure on other producers would rise, leading to lower prices on goods made in Mexico, India, Vietnam, and even the US. Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, when you think about it, is equivalent to a huge decrease in US household income. Something like, um, $250 billion per year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And, here's the other big point: If we remove our tariffs, China probably won't remove theirs. They never characterized their increases as retaliatory, so they have no incentive to back down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, here's the other big point: If we remove our tariffs, China probably won't remove theirs. They never characterized their increases as retaliatory, so they have no incentive to back down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given that China has always characterized its tariff increases on US goods as retaliatory, one can assume that it would remove them if the Trump tariffs were reversed.

dialogue_turns.text: So, US firms lose out, jobs diminish, incomes drop for exporters. And this is all happening while Biden is facing a tough election, with the cost of living being voters' number one concern.

dialogue_turns.text: But the author makes a really strong case, saying it's, uh, a "failure of leadership" if Biden doesn't communicate to voters that maintaining these tariffs is actually beneficial for American households and firms.
